perturbation.original_text: Any payment required to be made by Sponsor hereunder that is not paid within fourteen (14) days from the date such payment becomes due and owing shall bear interest at an annual rate of twelve percent (12%) per annum or, if lower, the maximum allowed by law from the due date to the date payment is actually made.
perturbation.changed_text: Any payment required to be made by Sponsor hereunder that is not paid within five (5) days from the date such payment becomes due and owing shall bear interest at an annual rate of twenty-five percent (25%) per annum from the due date to the date payment is actually made.
perturbation.explanation: California law restricts the amount of interest that can be charged on late payments, especially in commercial transactions. Charging 25% interest after only 5 days is potentially usurious and violates California's usury laws (California Constitution Article XV Section 1), creating a legal contradiction.

perturbation.original_text: Termination of this Agreement shall be effective thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of such notice, unless, within thirty (30) days after receipt of such notice, the defaulting Party has corrected the default or if such default is capable of correction, has taken timely and reasonable steps to correct and will complete such correction within another thirty (30) days.
perturbation.changed_text: Termination of this Agreement shall be effective ten (10) days from the date of receipt of such notice, unless, within ten (10) days after receipt of such notice, the defaulting Party has corrected the default or if such default is capable of correction, has taken timely and reasonable steps to correct and will complete such correction within another ten (10) days.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a default to 10 days may be considered unreasonably short, especially for complex contractual breaches. This could violate the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under California contract law, which requires parties to act reasonably and honestly in their contractual relations. This is a legal contradiction to the implicit protection afforded by the covenant of good faith.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California's implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing

perturbation.original_text: All notices, requests, or offers required or permitted to be made under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed properly delivered on the earlier of actual receipt or three days after the date deposited in the U.S. Mail, by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by recognized overnight delivery service with signature required (e.g., FedEx, UPS) addressed as follows:
perturbation.changed_text: All notices, requests, or offers required or permitted to be made under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed properly delivered immediately after the date deposited in the U.S. Mail, by regular mail addressed as follows:
perturbation.explanation: California law requires specific notice procedures for certain types of legal communication. Eliminating the requirements for certified mail, return receipt, or overnight delivery and stating that notice is effective immediately upon mailing by regular mail could be deemed insufficient for critical legal notices, potentially violating due process and California's code of civil procedure regarding service of legal documents.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Civil Procedure regarding service of legal documents and Due Process
